questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between Flexbox and CSS Grid?

answer_variants.answer: Flexbox is for 1D layouts (Row OR Column). Grid is for 2D layouts (Rows AND Columns).

Flexbox is one-dimensional and content-first (it arranges items based on their size/content). CSS Grid is two-dimensional and layout-first (it defines a strict template structure into which items are placed).
Flexbox operates on a single Main Axis. Grid operates on two axes (Block and Inline) simultaneously, allowing complex spanning (`grid-column: 1 / 3`) and layering.
Flexbox is 1-dimensional. Grid is 2-dimensional.
Flexbox is a string of pearls (linear). Grid is a chessboard (checkerboard).
Flexbox = 1D; Grid = 2D.

Use Flexbox for alignment of items within a component (like a navbar or card). Use Grid for the overall page structure or complex image galleries where vertical alignment across different rows is required.
Flexbox puts things in a single line. Grid puts things in a table-like box.
Wait, Grid can also be 1D (`grid-template-columns: 1fr`), but it lacks the content-wrapping fluidity of `flex-wrap` unless auto-fill/auto-fit is used.
Flexbox is one-dimensional layout model. CSS Grid Layout is a two-dimensional layout system.

questions.question: What does `justify-content` control in a Flex container?

answer_variants.answer: It controls the alignment of items along the main horizontal axis.

It defines how the browser distributes space between and around flex items along the **Primary Axis** (Row by default). Common values include `center`, `space-between`, `space-around`, and `flex-start`.
It aligns items along the Main Axis defined by `flex-direction`. If direction is `row`, it aligns horizontally. If `column`, it aligns vertically.
It aligns items horizontally (assuming flex-direction: row).
It's like justifying text in Word. Left align, Center, Best Fit (Space between).
Aligns items on the main axis (usually horizontal).
A crucial distinction: `justify-content` deals with *free space distribution*. If there is no free space (items fill the container), `space-around` or `center` will look identical.
It decides if the items sit on the left, right, middle, or spread evenly across the row.
It also works in Grid items to align the grid track content.
The justify-content property defines how the browser distributes space between and around content items along the main-axis of a flex container.

questions.question: What is the function of `align-items` in Flexbox?

answer_variants.answer: It aligns items vertically (perpendicular to the row).
It controls default alignment along the **Cross Axis** (Vertical by default). `stretch` is the default, making items full-height. `center` is used for vertical centering.
Controls alignment on the Cross Axis. Unlike `align-content` (which aligns packed rows), `align-items` aligns the individual items within their specific flex line.
It aligns items on the Cross Axis.
If Justify is Left/Right, Align is Top/Bottom.
Aligns items on the cross axis (vertical).
To perfectly center a div, you set both `justify-content` (X) and `align-items` (Y) to `center` on the parent.
It moves things up or down inside the box. Usually used to center text vertically.
The `baseline` value is super useful for aligning text of different font sizes.
The align-items property defines the default behavior for how flex items are laid out along the cross axis on the current line.

questions.question: What does the `fr` unit represent in CSS Grid?

answer_variants.answer: It stands for 'Fraction'. `1fr` takes up 1 part of the available space.

The `fr` unit represents a 'Fraction of the Available Space'. In `1fr 2fr`, the available space is split into 3 parts: first column gets 1/3, second gets 2/3. It is superior to percentages because it calculates space *after* fixed width (px) items are placed.
A flexible length that describes a share of the free space in the grid container.
Fractional Unit.
It's like slicing a cake. `1fr 1fr` means 'Cut it in half'. `1fr 3fr` means 'I get one slice, you get three slices'.
One fraction of the free space.
Using `repeat(3, 1fr)` automatically creates three equal columns that resize responsively. It avoids the math of `33.333%` and handles gaps correctly.
It divides the empty space up. 1fr is one share.
`minmax(0, 1fr)` is a common pattern because default `1fr` can sometimes blow out if the content is too wide (min-content).
Fractional Unit. 1fr is one part of the available space in the grid container.

questions.question: What is the modern way to center an element horizontally and vertically?

answer_variants.answer: `display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;`

The standard solution is Flexbox: set the parent to `display: flex`, then `justify-content: center` (Main Axis) and `align-items: center` (Cross Axis). Alternatively, CSS Grid can do it with `display: grid; place-items: center;`.
The 'Holy Grail' layout. Flexbox method works better for content block centering. Grid method (`place-items: center`) is terser.
Use Flexbox properties justify-content and align-items.
It's setting the crosshairs on target center.
`display: grid; place-items: center;` is the shortest way.
Before Flexbox, this required `position: absolute; top: 50%; left: 50%; transform: translate(-50%, -50%);`, which was hacky and could cause blurring on half-pixels.
Make the parent a flexbox and tell it to center everything in both directions.
The `margin: auto` trick also works inside Flex/Grid containers.
.center { display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; }

questions.question: Why does `z-index` often fail to work on a `<div>`?

answer_variants.answer: Because the `position` property is missing (defaults to `static`).
`z-index` only applies to positioned elements (`relative`, `absolute`, `fixed`, `sticky`) or Flex/Grid items. If `position` is `static` (default), the z-index value is ignored entirely.
The element must be part of a Stacking Context. Static elements are part of the normal flow layer (z-index auto). Setting `position: relative` creates a new context reference.
The element is likely `position: static`.
It is like trying to change the altitude of a building. You can't. You have to put it on a hovering platform (Positioned) first, then you can fly it up (Z-Index).
Set `position: relative` (or anything not static).
Sometimes it fails because of 'Stacking Context' isolation. If a parent has `opacity: 0.99`, it creates a new stacking context, trapping the child's z-index inside that parent.
You forgot to add `position: relative`. Z-index needs Position to work.
Modern CSS: `isolation: isolate` can also manage stacking contexts without position hacks.
Z-index only works on positioned elements (position: absolute, relative, fixed, or sticky) and flex items.

questions.question: What is the stacking order rule for elements with the same `z-index`?

answer_variants.answer: The one that appears later in the HTML code sits on top.
DOM Order (Source Order) looks. If z-indices are identical (or both auto), the element defined lower down in the markup is painted last, meaning it appears 'on top'.
Last In, First On Top. This is the 'Painters Algorithm'. 1. Background. 2. Low Z-index. 3. Source Order for same z-index. 4. High Z-index.
The element defined later in the HTML shows on top.
It's like stacking papers. If you put Paper A down, then Paper B, Paper B is on top.
Last element in code wins.
This is why you don't always need `z-index`. Often just moving the modal `<div>` to the bottom of the `<body>` is enough to make it appear over everything.
The one written last sits on top.
Shadow DOM changes this slightly, but standard Light DOM follows source order strictly.
If two positioned elements overlap without a z-index specified, the one defined later in the HTML code will show on top.

questions.question: What is the behavior of `overflow: hidden`?

answer_variants.answer: It cuts off any content that sticks out of the box.
`overflow: hidden` clips content that exceeds the element's dimensions. It does NOT add scrollbars. It is also commonly used to 'clear' floats in older layouts.
The content is clipped to the padding box. No scrolling mechanism is provided to the user. Programmatic scrolling (`scrollTo`) typically still works.
The overflow is clipped, and the rest of the content will be invisible.
It's like a picture frame with glass. If the photo is too big, you just cut off the edges. You can't see what's outside the frame.
Clips content; no scrollbars.
Using `overflow: hidden` on the `body` is a common technique to prevent background scrolling when a Modal is open.
It hides anything that spills out. Like trimming the edges of a sandwich.
It establishes a new Block Formatting Context (BFC), which is why it used to be the go-to 'float fixer'.
The overflow is clipped, and the rest of the content will be invisible.

questions.question: Which combination of properties is required to create a text ellipsis (`...`)?

answer_variants.answer: `white-space: nowrap`, `overflow: hidden`, and `text-overflow: ellipsis`.
You need three properties on a block container: 1. `white-space: nowrap` (forces one line), 2. `overflow: hidden` (hides spillover), 3. `text-overflow: ellipsis` (renders the dots).
`text-overflow: ellipsis` only triggers if the box overflows. Since text wraps by default, you must force single-line (`nowrap`) and hide the overflow.
text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap; overflow: hidden;
Force the sentence onto one line. Cut off the end. Put three dots at the crime scene.
nowrap + hidden + ellipsis.
Multi-line ellipsis is harder and usually requires `-webkit-line-clamp` (a non-standard but widely supported property).
Make it one line. Hide the extra text. Tell CSS to show dots.
It requires the element to have a defined width (or max-width) to know when to trigger.
Use text-overflow: ellipsis; along with white-space: nowrap; and overflow: hidden;.

questions.question: What is the `gap` property used for in CSS Grid (and Flexbox)?

answer_variants.answer: It adds empty space between rows and columns.

It defines the gutters (spacing) between Grid rows and columns (or Flex items). It replaces the old need for margin hacks (like negative margins on containers). It accepts one value (`gap: 10px`) or two (`gap: 10px 20px` for row/col).
Shorthand for `row-gap` and `column-gap`. It applies to multi-column layout, flex layout, and grid layout.
Space between grid cells.
Like the mortar between bricks. It spaces them out uniformly.
Separation space between Grid/Flex items.
Previously called `grid-gap`. The `grid-` prefix was dropped so it could be reused in Flexbox (`display: flex; gap: 10px;`).
It puts space between your boxes without adding space around the outside.
Unlike margins, gaps do not collapse. They are always additive.
The gap property defines the size of the gap between the rows and columns.
